article.headline: A âpowerful forceâ will determine what happens next in the stock market, Wharton professor predicts
article.body: “ âItâs not going to be a serious correction, not anywhere again down near those March lows. A little pause if we get that wave, but I donât think itâs going to really stop the longer-term momentum upward.â ” Thatâs Jeremy Siegel, the Wharton professor credited for calling Dow 20,000 in 2015, talking with CNBC about his bullish market outlook despite the potential for a surge in coronavirus cases. He explained that, ultimately, the combination of an effective vaccine and a government committed to pumping the economy with stimulus should provide a tailwind for the stock market. âEven if it takes another six months more than we hope to get an effective vaccine, when you come back with the liquidity thatâs provided by the Fed, thatâs a really powerful force,â Siegel said. Considering stocks are forward-looking assets, he explained that the market should hold up in the coming months even with lousing economic numbers and a lingering pandemic. âThatâs why you can have a âUâ economy, a âWâ economy, and you can still have a âVâ stock market,â Siegel said. Read:That V-shaped economic recovery? Donât count on it, warns âDr. Doomâ In reference to the increasingly popular Wall Street theme that value stocks will return as tech stock run out of gas, Siegel told CNBC it doesnât have to be one or the other. âThe amount of the liquidity thatâs been added to this economy is there. Itâs not going to be withdrawn by the Fed because unemployment is going to remain high,â he said. âSo I think thereâs room really for both groups to go up in 2021, even though we finally might get a turn towards value.â Watch the full interview: Meanwhile the stock market hit a bit of a speed bump on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.56% Â and S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% Â moving lower. The Nasdaq Composite COMP, +1.39% Â , however, managed to push into positive territory.
